title: CEO says Australia's '18th century relic' education system is to blame for its 'cactus' economy
text:
A multimillionaire CEO has slammed Australia's education system as an '18th century relic' and says it is to blame for our 'cactus' economy.

Matt Barrie is a technology entrepreneur who believes the Australian education system is flawed because it's training people for jobs the country doesn't need or that aren't available.

The 46-year-old said high-achievers are being strangled by the system into degrees such as law and medicine, with no opportunity for growth in industries requiring advanced skills.

He believes this stagnation of growth is putting Australia on the back foot compared to global markets.

Mark Barrie (pictured) called Australia's education system an '18th century relic' and thinks it is to blame for our 'cactus' economy

Mr Barrie believes that high-achievers are being strangled by the system into degrees such as law and medicine, with no opportunity for growth in industries requiring advanced skills (stock image)

'That’s why there’s no productivity, because we’re producing people to serve cups of coffee and serve avocado on toast to each other,' Mr Barrie told news.com.au.

'We’ve got to fix the secondary school system, which is an 18th century relic, training people for jobs that don’t exist.'

Mr Barrie believes Australian teachers are reluctant to embrace technology, which leaves school leavers strapped after completing their studies with no avenues available to study technical skills.

'It’s the teachers that are holding things back, and because it’s all controlled by the state governments you have all this duplication, bureaucracy, glacial movement of the system and all these entrenched people in positions that you just need to reinvent it,' he said.

Instead of focusing on well-worn paths, Mr Barrie thinks putting skilled young people in growing industries to start businesses and train employees will ignite a spark in Australia's advanced skills industry.

He believes by investing in specialised schools we will develop highly skilled applicants in positions we need to produce services and products we need for the future.
description: A multimillionaire CEO has called Australia's education system an '18th century relic' and thinks it is to blame for our 'cactus' economy.
authors: Jackson Barron For Daily Mail Australia
